results.title: I keep remembering Ita (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A videotape and study guide about the positive role of older people in the community. It presents three distinct personal portraits of older women and three different approaches to growing older. Each portrait shows older people taking charge of their lives. The women portrayed have a positive attitude to themselves and their community. Study guide available.

results.title: I Keep Remembering Ita (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A video about the positive role of older people in the community. Through three distinctive personal portraits of older women, and their approach to growing older we see how all three take charge of their lives and have a positive attitude to themselves and their community.

results.title: I keep remembering Ita
results.creator_credit: Oceania Media Network and Anne Bourke
results.brief_description: Many older people can play an important role in our community because of their skills, knowledge and experience. However, the media often portray older people as a hidden group. Politically they very often remain the victims despite changing attitudes. “I Keep Remembering Ita” presents three distinctive personal portraits of older women with three different approaches to growing older. Each portrait shows older people taking charge of their lives with the help of a positive mental attitude towards themselves and their community.

Each portrait shows older people taking charge of their lives with the help of a positive mental attitude towards themselves and their community.

results.title: I just work here
results.creator_credit: Roundtable Productions and Leon S. Gold
results.brief_description: Shows how customer service can be improved when the person providing the service makes an extra effort to understand the customer’s point of view and does not rigidly adhere to the rules.

results.title: I Is for important
results.brief_description: The film covers examples of sex role stereotyping in social interaction and emotional expression in schools. The scenes include sex role bias in disciplinary actions and student task assignments and children’s resistance to role reversal in kindergarten play.

results.title: I have Turkish blood in my body, how can I put it off? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Neil Munro
results.brief_description: An interview with two Turkish girls living in Australia which highlights family life in Turkish culture in comparison to Anglo Australian family life. Further it demonstrates clearly the substantial differences between sub-groups in the Turkish community.

results.title: I hate to lose
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, Michael Rubbo and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Filmed in the predominantly anglophone, upper middle-class Montreal riding of Westmount during the months preceding Quebec’s history-making election of November 15, 1976. ‘I hate to lose’ documents a play within a play, a brisk, natural drama that sparkles with humour. The camera follows closely behind leading political contenders George Springate, Nick Auf der Maur, and Harold ‘Shorty’ Fairhead, chronicling the unfolding of an election campaign on the local hustings, and gleaning retrospective insights into aglophone neglect of the Parti Quebecois’s swelling popularity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Daly, Michael Rubbo and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: I dream of peace and rest: Norman Lindsay
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Dale McCrea
results.brief_description: The opening of Norman Lindsay’s house by the National Trust. The house exhibits work by Norman Lindsay, including sculpture in the gardens. Lindsay’s thoughts and reflections on his life and work are heard, and many of his works of art are shown. Narrated by Margaret Throsby and Don Reid.

results.title: I do and I understand
results.creator_credit: John Arnold, Graphic Films, Nuffield Foundation and Derek Williams
